speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me when your diarrhea started and how long you've been experiencing it? Was it sudden or did it come on gradually?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started about two days ago, and it's been getting worse. I'd say it came on pretty suddenly, I was feeling fine and then all of a sudden I had to run to the bathroom with watery diarrhea, and it's been happening nonstop since then."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you recently traveled anywhere or eaten anything unusual that might have triggered this sudden onset of diarrhea? Have you also experienced any other symptoms such as fever, abdominal pain, or vomiting?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I haven't traveled anywhere recently or eaten anything out of the ordinary. As for other symptoms, I have been having some lower abdominal discomfort and cramping, but no fever or vomiting. The cramping has been pretty uncomfortable, especially after I use the bathroom."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the color and consistency of your stool, and have you noticed any blood or mucus in it? Have you also experienced any urgency or incontinence with your bowel movements?

speaker: Patient
text: "The stool is just watery, no blood or mucus that I've seen. And yes, the urgency is terrible - I have to go right away when I feel the need, and sometimes I'm not even sure I'll make it to the bathroom in time. It's been really embarrassing and stressful."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you been taking any medications or supplements recently that could be contributing to your diarrhea, and have you noticed any triggers that make it worse, such as certain foods or stress? REQUEST TEST: Complete Blood Count.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Hemoglobin: 13 g/dL, Total Count WBC: 13,400/mm3, Differential Count: Neutrophils: 80%, Lymphocytes: 15%, Monocytes: 5%

speaker: Doctor
text: Your white blood cell count is slightly elevated, which could indicate an infectious or inflammatory cause for your diarrhea. Can you tell me if you've been around anyone else who's been sick recently, such as a family member or coworker with similar symptoms? REQUEST TEST: Stool Culture.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Pending

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you think of any possible exposures to contaminated food or water that might have led to this infection, such as eating at a new restaurant or drinking unpasteurized juice? Have you had any close contact with children or adults who may have had similar gastrointestinal symptoms recently? REQUEST TEST: Ova and Parasite Exam.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed if your diarrhea is worse after eating certain foods, such as dairy or spicy foods, and do you have any underlying medical conditions that could be contributing to your symptoms? REQUEST TEST: Electrolyte Panel.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your diet over the past few days, have you consumed any foods that are high in sugar or spicy, and have you noticed if drinking anything in particular makes your symptoms better or worse? REQUEST TEST: Stool OVA and parasite repeat to confirm the previous result.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've had any recent antibiotic use or exposure to someone who has been taking antibiotics, and have you noticed if your symptoms are worse at any particular time of day or after certain activities? REQUEST TEST: Clostridioides difficile toxin assay.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Not specified

speaker: Doctor
text: It looks like we're still waiting on some test results, but I'd like to ask, have you experienced any symptoms at night, such as waking up to use the bathroom or having diarrhea during the night? And can you tell me if you've had any previous episodes of diarrhea or gastrointestinal issues in the past? REQUEST TEST: Endoscopy.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any improvement or worsening of your symptoms since we started running these tests, and have you had any episodes of diarrhea that were particularly severe or persistent? REQUEST TEST: Upper GI Series.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like all the test results so far are not indicating a clear cause for your diarrhea. Can you tell me if you've noticed any relation between your bowel movements and food intake, such as diarrhea immediately after eating, and have you tried avoiding any specific foods to see if it makes a difference? REQUEST TEST: Fecal Fat Test.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: It's concerning that all the test results so far are normal, yet your symptoms persist. Can you tell me if you've experienced any stress or anxiety recently, as sometimes emotional factors can contribute to gastrointestinal issues? Have you also noticed any changes in your appetite or weight since the diarrhea started? REQUEST TEST: Giardia antigen test.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily routine and stress levels, as we've ruled out many of the common causes of infectious diarrhea and I'm starting to consider other possibilities, such as irritable bowel syndrome or a functional gastrointestinal disorder? Have you noticed any correlation between your stress levels and the severity of your symptoms? REQUEST TEST: Lactoferrin stool test.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like all the tests we've run so far have come back normal, which is making it a bit challenging to pinpoint the exact cause of your diarrhea. Can you tell me if you've noticed any other symptoms besides the diarrhea and abdominal cramping, such as bloating, gas, or nausea? Have you also experienced any changes in your bowel habits, such as constipation or alternating between diarrhea and constipation? REQUEST TEST: Colonoscopy.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: I'm concerned that despite all the normal test results, your symptoms persist. Can you tell me if you've noticed any relief from your diarrhea when you're not eating or if you've tried a bland diet, and have you experienced any family history of gastrointestinal disorders? REQUEST TEST: Small intestine bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) breath test.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: We've ruled out many potential causes for your diarrhea, and I'm starting to consider less common possibilities. Can you tell me if you've noticed any symptoms outside of the gastrointestinal system, such as joint pain, skin rashes, or eye problems, that could be related to an underlying inflammatory condition? REQUEST TEST: Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: 33 mm/hr

speaker: Doctor
text: Your erythrocyte sedimentation rate is slightly elevated at 33 mm/hr, which could indicate an underlying inflammatory process. Can you tell me if you've noticed any other symptoms such as fatigue, headaches, or muscle aches that could be related to this inflammation? REQUEST TEST: C-Reactive Protein.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: With your C-Reactive Protein results being normal, it's a bit surprising given the slightly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Can you tell me if you've noticed any other symptoms that might seem unrelated to your diarrhea, such as mouth sores, hair loss, or unexplained bruising? REQUEST TEST: ANA panel to check for autoimmune disorders.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text:
DIAGNOSIS READY: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) 

The majority of the doctors agree that the patient's symptoms, such as sudden onset watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and urgency, along with the normal test results for infectious causes, point towards a diagnosis of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS). The absence of fever, vomiting, blood or mucus in the stool, and normal inflammatory markers further support this diagnosis. Although some doctors initially considered an infectious or inflammatory cause, the comprehensive array of tests with normal results led them to lean towards a functional gastrointestinal disorder like IBS. 

Note: Cholecystitis was mentioned as a possible answer but it is not supported by the discussion among the doctors, as none of them mentioned symptoms or test results consistent with cholecystitis, such as right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, or elevated liver enzymes.
